Kota Bekasi Wajibkan Restoran Punya Pengolahan Limbah, Sebab..
03 Nov 2019, 09:01 by Adi Warsono (Kontributor), Dwi Arjanto
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta -Pemerintah Kota Bekasi, Jawa Barat meminta semua rumah makan di wilayahnya membuat instalasi pengolahan air limbah (IPAL). Dorongan ini untuk menekan pencemaran lingkungan akibat limbah yang masuk ke saluran air.
Kepala UPTD IPALD Dinas Perumahan, Permukiman dan Pertanahan Kota Bekasi, Andrea Sucipto mengatakan, bisnis kuliner menjadi penyumbang terbesar pencemaran akibat limbahnya.
"Karena mereka setiap hari produksi, limbah cair yang dihasilkan cukup tinggi," kata Andrea di Bekasi pada Ahad, 3 November 2019.
Ia menyebut limbah bisnis kuliner berupa hasil cucian piring dan lainnya. Limbah itu semestinya diolah di instalasi pengolahan limbah sebelum dibuang ke saluran dalam kondisi steril. "IPAL semacam septik tank, tapi skalanya lebih besar," kata Andrea.
Membuat IPAL untuk bisnis kuliner cukup mudah, hanya dibutuhkan lahan paling besar 2X1 meter. Menurut dia, jika tak mau repot membuat instalasi sendiri, IPAL pabrikan cukup banyak di pasaran. "Tinggal ditanam, bisa langsung dipakai. Kalau untuk warteg, cukup buat seperti septik tank saja," ujar dia.
Banyaknya bangunan untuk bisnis kuliner belum memiliki IPAL, instansinya telah melayangkan sekitar 70 surat teguran hasil pengecekan secara random sampling. Pemerintah memberikan tenggat hingga 60 hari kedepan. Jika tak ada perbaikan, maka akan dilayangkan surat teguran. "Jika belum juga, SP 3 berupa rekomendasi pencabutan izin," kata Andrea.
Andrea mengatakan, kepemilikan IPAL di setiap rumah makan sesuai dengan Peraturan Daerah Nomor 5 Tahun 2018 tentang Pengolahan Air Limbah. Dalam aturan tersebut, pemerintah tegas meminta agar limbah domestik, limbah non-kakus atau grey water atay black water sebaiknya tidak dibuang ke saluran air.
Sekretaris Dinas Perumahan dan Permukiman, dan Pertanahan Kota Bekasi, Imas Asiah menambahkan, saat ini pihaknya baru dalam tahap sosialisasi.
Pada 2020 mendatang, pengawasan akan lebih ketat. "Masih ada toleransi buat pengusaha makanan karena kami masih sosialisasi Perda Kota Bekasi yang ada tahun ini," ucap Imas.

Bekasi City Require Restaurants to Have Waste Management, Because ...
03 Nov 2019, 09:01 by Adi Warsono (Contributor), Dwi Arjanto
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - The City Government of Bekasi, West Java has asked all restaurants in its area to make wastewater treatment plants (IPAL). This drive is to reduce environmental pollution due to waste entering the waterways.
Head of the Bekasi UPTD Department of Housing, Settlements and Land Services, Andrea Sucipto, said the culinary business was the biggest contributor to pollution caused by its waste.
"Because they produce every day, the wastewater generated is quite high," Andrea said in Bekasi on Sunday, November 3, 2019.
He mentioned culinary business waste in the form of dish washing and others. The waste should be treated in a waste treatment plant before being discharged into the channel in sterile conditions. "WWTPs are like septic tanks, but the scale is bigger," Andrea said.
Making an WWTP for a culinary business is quite easy, it only takes the biggest land area of 2X1 meters. According to him, if you do not want to bother making your own installation, there are quite a lot of IPALs on the market. "All that remains is planted, it can be used immediately. If it is for the warteg, it is enough to make it like a septic tank," he said.
The number of buildings for culinary business does not yet have WWTPs, the institution has sent around 70 warning letters from random sampling checks. The government provides a deadline of up to 60 days. If there is no improvement, a reprimand letter will be issued. "If not yet, SP 3 is in the form of a license revocation recommendation," said Andrea.
Andrea said, IPAL ownership in every restaurant is in accordance with Regional Regulation No. 5 of 2018 concerning Waste Water Treatment. In this regulation, the government firmly requests that domestic waste, non-latrine waste or gray water or black water should not be discharged into waterways.
The Secretary of the Bekasi City Housing and Settlements and Land Agency, Imas Asiah added, at this time his party was only in the stage of socialization.
In 2020, supervision will be tighter. "There is still tolerance for food entrepreneurs because we are still socializing the Bekasi City Regulation, this year," said Imas.
